conclusion.p: A function is a rule that may be in the form of a graph, or a table of values or a formula. It may even be a sentence or a set of instructions. A function takes an input value and uses the rule to create an output value.
Function notation looks like this: f(\text{input})=\text{output}

But, instead of writing the words input and output we usually use variables, like x and y. Then we define in words what the variables actually mean or represent. Most often the notation will look something like this: f(x)=y
Inside the parentheses is the Independent Variable, like x, and outside the parentheses, on the other side of the equals sign, is the Dependent Variable, like y.

example.p: Let E be the fuel efficiency, in miles per gallon, of a car traveling at s miles per hour. For speeds between 5 and 75 miles per hour, the function in tells us the efficiency of the car.
Therefore, the efficiency is a function of the speed. Using function notation we could write an equation saying the same thing: E=f(s)
The input is the speed, s, and the output is the efficiency, E.
The efficiency of the car is given by the height of the graph. Therefore f(35) = 28 means, The efficiency of the car traveling at 35 is 28 mpg.

paragraphs.title: Inputs have unique outputs
paragraphs.p: An important property of functions is that any single input value can only have one output value. For instance, the car can only have one efficiency at a given speed. The car cannot get 10 mpg and 20 mpg simultaneously.

However, it is possible there are multiple inputs that give you the same output. From the graph we see that a fuel efficiency of 25 mpg can be attained by traveling at a speed of about 20 and also at about 70.

paragraphs.title: Describing functions with intervals.
paragraphs.p: A function may have many different characteristics: Its output values may increase or decrease, its graph may curve up or curve down, it may have positive outputs or negative outputs. When describing these characteristics for a function, we typically refer to an interval (connected part) of the input axis, or a particular value of the input where something interesting occurs.

Using our efficiency example, the fuel efficiency increases (goes up) between 5 and 55 then decreases (goes down) for speeds between 55 and 75. Also, the efficiency is lowest at about 5 and highest at about 55.
Any connected portion of the horizontal (speed) axis or the vertical (efficiency) axis is called an interval. It is important to be able to correctly describe an interval.
We could use an inequality to describe the interval where the efficiency function is increasing: 5\lt s\lt55. This means that as the car's speed changes from 5 to 55, the efficiency is increasing.

paragraphs.title: Evaluating vs. Solving.
paragraphs.p: The word Evaluate means to use a known input value to find the output value. Evaluating a function looks like this:f(25)It means, Find the result of choosing 25 as the input. The expression f(25) represents the output 27, which we can see from the graph.

Solve means the output is already known and we are trying to find all the possible inputs that give us that output. These input values are called solutions of the equation. For instance, we may be asked to \text{Solve }f(s)=25This means that we are to find all input values (solutions) that would give us the output 25.
Using the graph of the efficiency function, we see that the equation f(s)=25 has two solutions: s = 20 and s = 70.

paragraphs.title: Average Rate of Change
paragraphs.p: This a very important topic of this course. You will see it over and over again in various forms. Basically it means slope, but it's more than that. It's also a notation and a concept that sets the stage for calculus.
From the car's efficiency function we know f(5)=10 which means at 5 the efficiency is 10.
We also know that f(25)=27 which means at 25 the efficiency is 27.
Therefore, as the speed increased from 5 to 25, the car's efficiency increased from 10 to 27. On average the efficiency changed by 17 while the speed changed by 20.
We can use this information to calculate the average increase in efficiency over the increase in speed.

The little triangle symbol \Delta is also very important. It means, Change in. Therefore \Delta f means change in efficiency and \Delta s means change in speed. Together the symbol \frac{\Delta f}{\Delta s} is called average rate of change.

paragraphs.title: Units
paragraphs.p: Units are the names of the quantities we are counting. In this example the units of efficiency are mpg (miles per gallon).
